topics.title: Introduction to Linux
topics.description: Understanding the Linux operating system, its architecture, and ecosystem

content.subtitle: What is Linux?
points: Open-source Unix-like operating system kernel created by Linus Torvalds in 1991
Forms the base of many distributions (distros) like Ubuntu, Debian, CentOS, Fedora, Arch
Powers servers, supercomputers, Android devices, and embedded systems
Free to use, modify, and distribute under GPL license

content.subtitle: Linux Architecture
points: Kernel: Core component managing hardware, memory, processes, and system calls
Shell: Command-line interface (bash, zsh, fish) for user interaction
System Libraries: Provide functions for applications (glibc, etc.)
System Utilities: Essential tools and programs (ls, cp, grep, etc.)
Desktop Environment: Optional GUI layer (GNOME, KDE, XFCE)

content.subtitle: Popular Distributions
points: Ubuntu/Debian: User-friendly, large community, apt package manager
Arch Linux: Rolling release, minimal base, pacman package manager
openSUSE: YaST configuration tool, zypper package manager

content.subtitle: Key Differences from Windows
points: Forward slashes for paths (/home/user) vs backslashes (C:\Users)
No drive letters - everything under root directory /
Text-based configuration files in /etc instead of registry

topics.title: Filesystem Hierarchy
topics.description: Understanding Linux directory structure and file organization

content.subtitle: Root Directory Structure
points: / - Root directory, top of filesystem hierarchy

content.subtitle: File Types
points: Regular files (-): Normal files containing data
Symbolic links (l): Shortcuts pointing to other files
Character devices (c): Serial devices like terminals
Block devices (b): Storage devices like hard drives

content.subtitle: Permissions System
points: Three permission types: read (r/4), write (w/2), execute (x/1)
Three user categories: owner, group, others
chmod 755 file = rwxr-xr-x (owner full, others read+execute)
chmod u+x file = add execute permission for owner
chown user:group file = change owner and group
Special permissions: SUID (4), SGID (2), Sticky bit (1)

content.subtitle: Path Types
points: Relative path: From current directory - documents/file.txt or ../file.txt

cd .. - Go up one directory level

ls -l - Long format with permissions, owner, size, date
ls -lh - Human-readable file sizes (KB, MB, GB)

content.subtitle: File Operations

content.subtitle: Viewing File Content

locate filename - Fast search using database

content.subtitle: grep - Pattern Searching
points: grep 'pattern' file - Search for pattern in file
grep -v 'pattern' file - Invert match (show non-matching lines)
grep -w 'word' file - Match whole words only
grep -A 3 'pattern' file - Show 3 lines after match
grep -B 3 'pattern' file - Show 3 lines before match

content.subtitle: Output Redirection

command 2> file - Redirect stderr to file
command &> file - Redirect both stdout and stderr

content.subtitle: Input Redirection
points: command < file - Read input from file

content.subtitle: Pipes and Command Chaining
points: cmd1 | cmd2 - Pipe stdout of cmd1 to stdin of cmd2
cmd1 && cmd2 - Run cmd2 only if cmd1 succeeds
cmd1 || cmd2 - Run cmd2 only if cmd1 fails
cmd1 ; cmd2 - Run cmd2 after cmd1 regardless of result
Example: ps aux | grep nginx | awk '{print $2}' - Get nginx PIDs
Example: cat file | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn - Frequency count

title: Network
content: Complete networking roadmap from fundamental concepts to advanced configurations

content.subtitle: What is a Computer Network?
points: Collection of interconnected devices that can communicate and share resources
Enables data exchange, resource sharing, and communication
Components: hosts (computers), network devices (routers, switches), transmission media
Uses protocols to establish rules for communication

content.subtitle: Network Types by Size
points: PAN (Personal Area Network): Very small, personal devices (Bluetooth, USB) - range: few meters
LAN (Local Area Network): Single building or campus - range: up to 1 km
MAN (Metropolitan Area Network): City-wide network - range: up to 50 km
WAN (Wide Area Network): Large geographical areas, countries - range: unlimited
Internet: Global network of networks connecting billions of devices worldwide

content.subtitle: Network Topologies
points: Bus: All devices on single cable, simple but single point of failure
Star: All devices connect to central hub/switch, easy to manage, hub is single point of failure
Ring: Devices in circular chain, data travels in one direction, failure breaks ring
Mesh: Every device connects to every other, highly redundant, expensive
Hybrid: Combination of topologies, most common in real networks

content.subtitle: Network Architectures
points: Client-Server: Centralized servers provide resources to clients, easier to manage and secure
Peer-to-Peer (P2P): All devices equal, share resources directly, no central server
Client-Server advantages: centralized control, better security, easier backup
P2P advantages: no server cost, more resilient, better for file sharing

topics.title: OSI Model
topics.description: Seven-layer reference model for network communication

content.subtitle: Layer 1 - Physical
points: Deals with physical transmission of raw bits over medium
Examples: Ethernet cables (Cat5e, Cat6), fiber optic, wireless radio
Specifications: cable length, signal strength, bit rate
No addressing or error correction at this layer

content.subtitle: Layer 2 - Data Link
points: Provides node-to-node data transfer and error detection
Uses MAC (Media Access Control) addresses for identification
Frames data with headers and trailers
Sublayers: LLC (Logical Link Control) and MAC
Devices: switches, bridges, network interface cards
Error detection using CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check)
MAC address format: 48 bits (6 bytes) - example: 00:1A:2B:3C:4D:5E

content.subtitle: Layer 3 - Network
points: Handles routing and forwarding of packets between networks
Determines best path for data delivery
Protocols: IP (IPv4, IPv6), ICMP, IGMP, IPsec
Performs fragmentation and reassembly of packets
Handles congestion control and quality of service (QoS)

content.subtitle: Layer 4 - Transport
points: Provides end-to-end communication and data delivery
Ensures complete data transfer with error recovery
Uses port numbers to identify applications (0-65535)
TCP features: three-way handshake, flow control, error correction, sequencing
UDP features: no connection setup, no reliability, lower overhead
Well-known ports: HTTP (80), HTTPS (443), SSH (22), DNS (53)

content.subtitle: Layer 5 - Session
points: Establishes, manages, and terminates sessions between applications
Synchronization and checkpointing for long transfers
Often combined with application layer in modern protocols

content.subtitle: Layer 6 - Presentation
points: Translates data between application and network formats
Ensures data is readable by receiving application

content.subtitle: Layer 7 - Application
points: Provides network services directly to end-user applications
Interface between network and application software
Protocols: HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SMTP, POP3, IMAP, DNS, DHCP, SSH, Telnet
Examples: web browsers, email clients, file transfer programs

content.subtitle: TCP/IP vs OSI
points: TCP/IP: 4 layers, practical implementation used in Internet
TCP/IP developed before OSI, more widely used
OSI provides better conceptual framework for learning

content.subtitle: Layer 1 - Network Access (Link)
points: Combines OSI Physical and Data Link layers
Handles physical transmission and local network access
Responsible for MAC addressing and frame delivery

content.subtitle: Layer 2 - Internet
points: Responsible for packet forwarding across networks

content.subtitle: Layer 3 - Transport
points: TCP: reliable, connection-oriented, used for web, email, file transfer
UDP: unreliable, connectionless, used for streaming, gaming, DNS

content.subtitle: Layer 4 - Application
points: Combines OSI Session, Presentation, and Application layers
Protocols: HTTP, FTP, SMTP, DNS, DHCP, SSH, Telnet
Handles data formatting, encryption, and user interface

sections.title: IP Addressing & Subnetting
sections.description: Understanding IP addresses and network division

topics.title: IPv4 Addressing
topics.description: Understanding IPv4 address structure and classes

content.subtitle: IPv4 Address Structure
points: Two parts: Network portion and Host portion
Subnet mask determines which bits are network vs host

content.subtitle: Address Classes
points: Class E: 240.0.0.0 to 255.255.255.255 - Reserved for research
Classful addressing is largely obsolete, replaced by CIDR

content.subtitle: Private vs Public Addresses
points: Private (RFC 1918): Not routable on Internet, used internally
Public addresses: Globally unique, routable on Internet
NAT (Network Address Translation) converts private to public

content.subtitle: Special Addresses
points: 255.255.255.255 - Limited broadcast (all hosts on local network)
Network address: First address in subnet (host bits all 0)
Broadcast address: Last address in subnet (host bits all 1)
169.254.0.0/16 - APIPA (Automatic Private IP Addressing) when DHCP fails

content.subtitle: Subnet Mask Basics
points: Determines network and host portions of IP address
Contiguous 1s for network, 0s for host bits

content.subtitle: Calculating Subnets
points: Formula: 2^h - 2 usable hosts (h = remaining host bits, -2 for network/broadcast)

content.subtitle: VLSM (Variable Length Subnet Mask)
points: Allows different subnet sizes within same network
More efficient use of IP address space
Example: /30 for point-to-point links (2 hosts), /24 for LANs (254 hosts)
Start with largest subnet requirements first
Requires classless routing protocols (OSPF, EIGRP, BGP)
Cannot use with RIPv1 or IGRP (classful protocols)

content.subtitle: Subnetting Practice
points: Given 10.0.0.0/8, need 1000 hosts per subnet: Use /22 (2046 hosts)
Point-to-point link needs only 2 IPs: Use /30 (2 usable hosts)
Online calculators available, but understand the math
Practice with different scenarios to build speed

content.subtitle: IPv6 Address Structure
points: Written as 8 groups of 4 hexadecimal digits
:: can only appear once in an address

content.subtitle: IPv6 Address Types
points: Unicast: One-to-one communication (Global, Link-local, Unique local)
Anycast: One-to-nearest communication (same as unicast format)
No broadcast in IPv6 (replaced by multicast)
Link-local: FE80::/10 - Not routable, local network only
Unique Local: FC00::/7 - Private addresses (like RFC 1918)

content.subtitle: IPv4 to IPv6 Transition
points: Dual Stack: Run both IPv4 and IPv6 simultaneously
Tunneling: Encapsulate IPv6 packets in IPv4 (6to4, Teredo)
Most modern systems support dual stack
IPv6 adoption growing but IPv4 still dominant
No direct compatibility between IPv4 and IPv6

content.subtitle: IPv6 Benefits
points: Vastly larger address space - no more exhaustion
Simplified header format - better routing efficiency
No need for NAT - end-to-end connectivity

content.subtitle: Ethernet Frames
points: Frame structure: Preamble, Destination MAC, Source MAC, Type, Data, FCS
Preamble: 7 bytes for synchronization + 1 byte Start Frame Delimiter
MAC addresses: 6 bytes each for source and destination
Type/Length: Indicates protocol (0x0800 for IPv4, 0x86DD for IPv6)
FCS (Frame Check Sequence): 4 bytes CRC for error detection
Minimum frame size: 64 bytes, Maximum: 1518 bytes (without VLAN tag)

content.subtitle: MAC Addressing
points: First 24 bits: OUI (Organizationally Unique Identifier) - manufacturer
Multicast MAC: First byte has least significant bit set to 1
Unicast MAC: First byte has least significant bit set to 0

content.subtitle: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol)
points: Maps IP addresses to MAC addresses on local network
ARP Request: Broadcast asking 'Who has IP X.X.X.X?'
ARP Reply: Unicast response 'I have IP X.X.X.X, my MAC is YY:YY:YY:YY:YY:YY'
ARP cache stores recent mappings (arp -a to view)
Gratuitous ARP: Announces own IP/MAC mapping
ARP spoofing: Security vulnerability, can be mitigated with DAI

content.subtitle: VLANs (Virtual LANs)
points: Reduces broadcast domains, improves security and performance
Access ports: Belong to single VLAN, for end devices
Trunk ports: Carry multiple VLANs, between switches
802.1Q tagging: Adds 4-byte VLAN tag to Ethernet frame
Native VLAN: Untagged traffic on trunk (default VLAN 1)

content.subtitle: IP (Internet Protocol)
points: Key fields: Version, Header Length, TTL, Protocol, Source/Dest IP
TTL (Time To Live): Decremented at each hop, prevents loops
Fragmentation: Splits large packets to fit MTU (typically 1500 bytes)
No error correction or retransmission - handled by upper layers

content.subtitle: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol)
points: Used for error reporting and diagnostics
Echo Request/Reply: Used by ping command
Destination Unreachable: Network, host, port, or protocol unreachable
Time Exceeded: TTL expired (used by traceroute)
Redirect: Informs host of better route
ping tests connectivity and measures round-trip time
traceroute uses TTL expiration to map network path

content.subtitle: IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol)
points: Hosts use IGMP to join/leave multicast groups
Routers use IGMP to discover which hosts want multicast traffic
IGMPv2: Added leave messages for faster response

content.subtitle: IPsec (IP Security)
points: Suite of protocols for securing IP communications
AH (Authentication Header): Provides authentication and integrity
ESP (Encapsulating Security Payload): Provides encryption and authentication
Transport mode: Encrypts only payload, used for end-to-end
Tunnel mode: Encrypts entire packet, used for VPNs
IKE (Internet Key Exchange): Negotiates security associations
Used in site-to-site and remote access VPNs
